awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2016
awd_abstract_narration:
Postdoctoral Fellow: Zaid McKie-Krisberg

Proposal Number: 1611916

This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2016, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups under-represented in biology.  The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Zaid McKie-Krisberg is "A Systems Approach to Investigations of Light Independent C4 Type Carbon Fixation in Green Algae." The host institutions for this fellowship are City University of New York-Brooklyn College and Rutgers University-Newark.  The sponsoring scientists are Drs. Juergen Polle and Adam Kustka. 

The Fellow?s research investigates whether green algae use the C4 pathway for photosynthesis. Understanding the genetic and molecular underpinnings of carbon (C) fixation by photosynthesis is important because C fixation by algae provides organic energy for nearly all aquatic food webs, and because algae photosynthesis can be an important source of biofuels. While there is some evidence that single-celled green algae use the C4 pathway (based on enzyme activity and the synthesis of organic C compounds), complete C4 photosynthetic pathways have yet to be confirmed in these algae, which are the closest relatives of vascular plants. In vascular plants, C4 pathways are associated with either a distinct multicellular anatomy, or with a diurnal rhythm. C4 pathways have been suggested to function as carbon concentrating mechanisms, contributing to pre-fixation of inorganic carbon.  However, in green algae, the products formed in these pathways can also be involved in synthesis of metabolites such as amino acids.  This suggests that C4 activity in green algae could be both 1) a mechanism to facilitate carbon availability for fixation, and 2) a connection between carbon and nitrogen metabolism. The Fellow is exploring the existence of C4 pathway activity and cellular organization in several species of green algae, using a comparative approach that integrates genomics, transcriptomics and proteomics, together with metabolic tracking experiments and molecular studies. 

The Fellow is being trained in systems biology, computational biology, and applied phycology, while advancing his development towards an independent academic career by publishing scientific articles, learning new techniques, and mentoring/training students. In an effort to broaden participation in science, the Fellow is drawing on the diverse populations at both host institutions to provide training and instruction in cutting edge biological research to students in under-represented groups. The Fellow is training undergraduate researchers, who are receiving training in bioinformatics theory and techniques, including biocuration and metabolic mapping.  In addition, the Fellow is creating a Systems Biology teaching module, which is being made available for public use by educators. In addition, the Fellow?s mentoring and training efforts are preparing undergraduate minority students for successful careers in STEM research.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided the Principle Investigator funding to investigate critical questions relevant to the evolution of photosynthetic pathways across different organisms, and among members of the green algal clade, in particular.  Specifically, the efforts performed as a result of this award have identified the presence of all enzymes required for several C4-related fixation pathways in the three green algae (Scenedemus obliquus, Coelastrella sp. (strain DOE0202), and Dunaliella salina).  In many cases multiple copies of enzymes were found, and this data was used to create species-specific metabolic model detailing these pathways in the context of the total carbon metabolism in these organisms.  This model was then used to overlay quantitative expression level data, such as the results of RNAseq data obtained from climate simulated ponds experiments.  In addition, shotgun proteomics analysis was performed, initially to confirm the presence of translational products consistent with the predicted gene models and transcriptional expression.  Continuing work will add quantitative proteomics to compare transcriptional and translational dynamics.

In terms of training, this project provided opportunity for the fellow to gain experience in many aspects of the systems biology approach.  This includes genomics, transcriptomics, and mass spectrometry-based proteomics. Gaining experience in sample preparation, genome/ transcriptome assembly, annotation, techniques, as well as proteogenomic approaches (leveraging genome annotations for efficient identification of peptide fragments), has collectively equipped the fellow with a robust toolkit, which would otherwise be difficult to obtain.  The continuing refinement of these skills will allow the fellow to make ongoing contributions to the field, and provide the opportunity to collaboration on a wide range of projects by utilizing some or all of these techniques to support future investigations of metabolism at the molecular level.  In addition, The identification of C4-related fixation pathway contributes to the current understanding of algal physiology, and the result of this project have already served as the basis for ongoing research conducted by groups such as those in the Algal Genomics working group, a shared consortium which includes researchers from several US National Laboratories, as well as university labs.

This project also contained a significant educational portion.  The fellow provided instruction to students both in the classroom, serving as a guest lecture for 2 weeks in the ?Environmental Biotechnology & Omics? course held at Rutgers University ? Newark as well as in the graduate level Molecular Biology course at Brooklyn College ? CUNY.  These lectures were primarily focused on RNAseq analysis, and the exercises developed for these courses will be made publically available to the educators in the field.  The fellow as trained several cohorts of students at Brooklyn College-CUNY in various aspects related to systems biology approaches.  This included principles of algal cultivation and sample preparation for DNA/RNA/Protein analysis.  The fellow also provided computational training in bioinformatics techniques, introducing students to scientific computing, pipeline development, and standard workflows involved in genome assemble, annotation, and well as RNAseq and proteomic analysis pipelines.   All student cohorts that participated in this project for the duration of the award, at the graduate, undergraduate, and even high school level, contained a significant number of students from groups under-represented in the field of biology.  This award has made a substantial contribution to providing these students an introduction to some of the most cutting edge tools in biology.  Many of the students participating in this research at the undergraduate level have moved on to pursue graduate training at leading institutions.

The results of this project have already resulted in the publication of manuscripts which have incorporated both the identity of specific points of interesting within enzymatic pathways, as well organismal scale metabolic networks.   Additional manuscripts produced as a result of this project are forthcoming and will increase the impact of the award on the scientific community.  Student research was presented at Department Colloquia at Brooklyn College-CUNY, and the fellow also presented this research at the 18th International Conference on the Cell and Molecular Biology of Chlamydomonas meeting in Washinton D.C., and the Algal Biomass Organization Summit 2018 meeting in Houston, TX. This work is also of interest to industry as it can provide targets for strain improvement relevant to algal biotechnology.  Also the improved genome assembly and annotation efforts have formed the bases for the successful submission of a additional funding requests, such as those for extensive proteomic profiling, which when coupled with transcript expression, can be analyzed using the metabolic network model, and provide resolution to the dynamics of photosynthetic carbon metabolism in algae, which would not be possible without this award.
